newsitem.title: USA: Carbide/Graphite, UCAR subpoenaed in price-fixing case.
newsitem.headline: Carbide/Graphite, UCAR subpoenaed in price-fixing case.

text.p: Carbide/Graphite Group Inc. and UCAR International Inc., both makers of electrodes, said separately Thursday they have been subpoenaed by a grand jury investigating price fixing by producers of graphite products in the United States and abroad.
Pittsburgh-based Carbide/Graphite said that in exchange for its cooperation, neither the company nor executives who cooperated would be prosecuted if charges are issued by the grand jury.
UCAR, based in Danbury, Conn., said it was subpoenaed and served with a related search warrant. UCAR is the world's largest maker of graphite and carbon electrodes.
It noted graphite electrodes, the company's principal product, are consumed primarily in the production of steel in electric arc furnaces and for refining steel in ladle furnaces.

"The antitrust division is looking at the possibility of anti-competitive practices in the graphite electrodes industry," said Gina Talamona, spokeswoman for antitrust division of the U.S. Department of Justice.
Carbide/Graphite stock dropped more than 14 percent, closing at $24.25, down $4.125 on Nasdaq. UCAR stock was off more than 13 percent, dropping $6.875 to $41.875 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Both UCAR and Carbide/Graphite said they were cooperating with the government in the investigation by the grand jury empanelled by the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.
The companies said the government has not yet determined that any laws have been broken.
